reviewText: This documentary film was very interesting and informative. This film sheds light on how Islam found its way to the Americas through slaves during the slave trade.
Loved it. Just shows that when a person is free, they would do anything to get that freedom back if it were ever taken away from them.

I watched this story twice on PBS last night and found it both entertaining
as well as educational. It also opened me up, as I had never heard of this story before...
A genuine african prince who gets captured and sold into slavery in the late
1700's / early 1800's, serves for 40 yrs under the brutal slavery system in the
Natchez Territory, which is now Mississippi, but once was owned by the spanish like Florida once was.
Though he is highly educated, civilized, and in fact speaks several languages and reads
and writes arabic fluently, this is overlooked and dismissed by his white slave owner,
who can only see his black skin and think of how he and several other slaves which he
has purchased can make him rich by working his land!
Remember, we were supposed to be godless ignorant uncivilized savages?? (-:
Kinda makes you wonder about the relativity of the words "ignorant" and "uncivilized" doesn't it?
A chance encounter with an unlikely ally turns this "Prince Among Slaves" fortunes around
and slowly but surely, he wins his freedom. But there are so many other layers to this story
that I don't want to give away in my review because I want you, the purchaser, to see it
for yourself so you can get the full emotional and intellectual impact of this moving story!
This is a worthwhile addition to your DVD collection if you like documentaries about
the early origins of America and it's evolution into becoming what it eventually became.
There is still more growth and understanding to be achieved between all the races
and cultures who make up our great american gumbo, even in this day & time when we've made
so many strides, yet true equality and understanding still elude us in many ways collectively.
Kudos to PBS for creating another great story!

I have always wondered why some African American folks have Muslim names, this movie answered my question!
Also for those who are seeking truth about the atrocities of the white man in the name of their religion, this is a must see movie.
I really enjoyed watching this movie.  I never thought about that many of the african slaves who were forced to come here to the U.S. were Muslim.  Very well done movie and this is a true story.

Most conscious people know a bit of Abdul Rahman's biography. But this documentary brings his life into detailed focus. I actually think his story is more of the norm than the exception.

I didn't know Rahman used the homeland of Morocco to his advantage, until President Adams found out he was from Gambia and withdrew his support.

It was nice to see the so called "Black" Masons (Prince Hall) rally around Rahman's cause and plight. Mos Def does part of the narration. I salute Abbie Shabazz on his procreation. Bill Duke directs this documentary and I can't help to marvel how far he has come from playing the angry Abdula in the movie "Car Wash" to directing such a meaningful work of liberal art. I commend Bill Duke and all involved for bringing the Abdul Rahman story to further light.

Hollywood really needs to take this story and move with it! PRINCE AMONG SLAVES is an hour long documentary on the true life events of one Abduhl Rahman,son of the Muslim King of Futa Jallon,who was sold by rival African tribes into Europeans hands and transported to America in 1788. Purchased by a Thomas Foster,"Prince" as he was to be called,serves 40 years as a slave,marries and sires nine children,and becomes political fodder for a Mississippi News Journalist,two Presidents,one Secretary of State and for the entire American Colonization Society in his fight for freedom and return to his homeland. This is a great and absolutely fascinating true story directed and written by Lloyd Jones, Andrea Kalin (American Experience - Partners Of The Heart) and Cannes nominated Bill Duke(The Killing Floor,Miracle's Boys,Hoodlum and Rage in Harlem)."Prince" Rahman's story reads like a fairytale,but it is pointed out,quite poignantly,that much about what is known at the time,may be greatly exaggerated due to how politically motivated certain players were in "using" Rahman's story. This documentary is narrated by Mos Def and is partially "talking heads" and partially below average re-enactment for a PBS Special. THAT is my only rub with this presentation. The budget may have been low and there is subpar acting,makeup and sets. There is nothing,though,subpar about the information presented here. Other suggested documentaries of similar interest would be The Middle Passage,The Voyage of La Amistad: A Quest for Freedom as well as the feature films Amazing Grace and Amistad.

This PBS documentary tells the story of an African Prince who is brought to Mississippi in the late 18th century.  It it a beautiful and moving story that I never heard in my US History classes.  The story of Abdul-Rahman is one of hope and perserverance and truly deserves more attention  I hope it is one day made into a feature film one day.  I definitely plan on reading the book now.
I watched this documentry on PBS, I never new this story exsisted, but I was glued to the tv for the full hour. It's a great heart felt tale of a struggle and triumph. Highly recommended!

This is a good documentary. It gives a very good historical perspective on the ugliness of slavery. It highlighted the many hardships, brutalities, and horrendous conditions faced by the slaves held in captivity against their will. This documentary shows the resilience of "Prince" to rise above his plight to seek freedom for himself and his family. This documentary was painful at times to watch but the actors gave a believable portrayal of their "circumstances". The dialogue between the characters was good and the dramatic scenes brought out in me emotions of empathy, anger, sadness, and hope. This documentary may have began back in the time of slavery but it gave me food for thought today of one example of how one person can shape the course of history for generations.

EXCELLENT.....AS AN AFRICAN AMERICAN, WE ALWAYS HEAR STORIES FROM THE ELDERS THAT WE COME FROM KINGS AND QUEENS, THIS FILM HELPS TO REALIZE THE SPIRITS THAT MOVE WITHIN OUR HEARTS AND MINDS.  LOVE ALWAYS.

I had never heard the story of the African prince.  It was so sad.  To come from royalty and be made a slave.  I can't even imagine.  He was able to make the best with what he had, which was quite admirable.  The  narrated documentary was a combination of mostly re-enactments interspersed with interviews.  Good pace.  Well-edited.

I do not recommend this movie because you will start to hate white Americans or at minimum view them differently. The African slavery was not better than Holocaust for me. Right now I understand why Americans love undocumented immigrants. No rights, little wages = new sort of slavery.
Inspired me to want to know of where I came from.

This provides another layer of complexity to a painful era in American History. Contrary to popular myth, the Africans brought to North America in chains were not uneducated savages. In the case of Prince Abdul Rahman, he was highly educated spoke and read numerous languages. He was in fact, more educated that his illiterate white slave owner.
I highly recommend this video as tool to explore the historical roots of white privilege. It glosses over the brutality of the slave trade and the slave market. Instead it focuses specifically on the concept that white men are inherently better and their interests trump everything else.  While the founding fathers were saying all men are created equal, the reality was,  they tolerated enormous amounts of inequality to win freedom from Britain. The history of this country since has been one of reconciling  freedom and equality.

More liberal crap out of Hollywood...it was tired and boring years ago, and still is.

Sadly others remain nameless and their legacies lost forever to the detriment of their ancestors here in the Americas and abroad. This is a beautiful, complicated tale with a bitter-sweet ending. It's narrated by Mos Def aka Yasin Bey which is cool. The relationship of African with Islam goes way back... before the Nation of Islam movement in the United States.

A true story about a man who was a prince in his native Africa. He was kidnapped  by slave traders. He spent  forty years in slavery in Mississippi  until a Scottish  doctor reconciled him, and tried unsuccessfully  to purchase  his freedom. Eventually  the State Department  and President  John Quincy  Adam got involve. Adul Rahman returned to Africa  with his wife where died four months later .

This was a wonderful story of the hardships one man went through in order to regain his freedom and to free his family as well. Abdul Rahman, son of an African Muslim King, is taken from his home and sold into slavery in Mississippi. He marries, starts a family and eventually gains a sort of freedom for himself.  A sort of freedom that enabled him to move among many social circles to raise funds to buy the freedom of his wife and children. This documentary tells a beautiful story with a surprising and emotional ending. Definitely worth watching.

It is ironic that a leader of the Fulani Muslims in Guinea who enslaved the local African population during the conquest in the 17th century is then taken as a slave  himself.  It would have been interesting to shed light on this history of the Muslim conquest of the Futa Djallon by the Fulani and the dominance over the Bantu peoples of the region.  Really a shame that he was never able to return to the Futa to see his family.  It is a beautiful region.  Unfortunately the former master/slave  relationships still exist there, and few Bantu actually own the land that they cultivate.

The importance of Abdul Rahman's story goes far beyond the evils of the trans-Atlantic slave trade and plantation economy. The timing and context of his situation overlaps with major shifts related to class, economics, politics, diplomacy, immigration, repatriation, racial and social identity and the rise of tabloid media in our young nation. The docudrama would benefit from a few more photos and maps

A lot of men would have given up a long time ago but he was a true PRINCE and I don't mean his title.  I highly recommend this movie to everyone.

This movie fell short for me. For one thing, we never really got to know the main character. Of course, we feel compassion for him and his plight, but what makes him so special? Why is he more important than any other enslaved black man? Because he was a prince, he is somehow better than everyone else and deserves better treatment? The story-based-in-fact was okay in the beginning, but when this man got his freedom, he did nothing to help free other slaves. His only goal was to free his own family and get back to his own soil. Then, after begging all across the land for money (instead of fighting for the freedom of enslaved peoples) he managed to free only two of his kids and took off for Africa anyway! The story had promise, but fell short. It's like they took a story that would take five minutes to tell, and made it into a full-length movie. I felt less compassion for this man than I've felt for just about any other enslaved human I've read about or seen in movies--and certainly less than any character in Roots.

I watched this story twice on PBS last night and found it both entertaining
as well as educational. It also opened me up, as I had never heard of this story before...
A genuine african prince who gets captured and sold into slavery in the late
1700's / early 1800's, serves for 40 yrs under the brutal slavery system in the
Natchez Territory, which is now Mississippi, but once was owned by the spanish like Florida once was.
Though he is highly educated, civilized, and in fact speaks several languages and reads
and writes arabic fluently, this is overlooked and dismissed by his white slave owner,
who can only see his black skin and think of how he and several other slaves which he
has purchased can make him rich by working his land!
Remember, we were supposed to be godless ignorant uncivilized savages?? (-:
Kinda makes you wonder about the relativity of the words "ignorant" and "uncivilized" doesn't it?
A chance encounter with an unlikely ally turns this "Prince Among Slaves" fortunes around
and slowly but surely, he wins his freedom. But there are so many other layers to this story
that I don't want to give away in my review because I want you, the purchaser, to see it
for yourself so you can get the full emotional and intellectual impact of this moving story!
This is a worthwhile addition to your DVD collection if you like documentaries about
the early origins of America and it's evolution into becoming what it eventually became.
There is still more growth and understanding to be achieved between all the races
and cultures who make up our great american gumbo, even in this day & time when we've made
so many strides, yet true equality and understanding still elude us in many ways collectively.
Kudos to PBS for creating another great story!

I have always wondered why some African American folks have Muslim names, this movie answered my question!
Also for those who are seeking truth about the atrocities of the white man in the name of their religion, this is a must see movie.
I really enjoyed watching this movie.  I never thought about that many of the african slaves who were forced to come here to the U.S. were Muslim.  Very well done movie and this is a true story.

Most conscious people know a bit of Abdul Rahman's biography. But this documentary brings his life into detailed focus. I actually think his story is more of the norm than the exception.

I didn't know Rahman used the homeland of Morocco to his advantage, until President Adams found out he was from Gambia and withdrew his support.

It was nice to see the so called "Black" Masons (Prince Hall) rally around Rahman's cause and plight. Mos Def does part of the narration. I salute Abbie Shabazz on his procreation. Bill Duke directs this documentary and I can't help to marvel how far he has come from playing the angry Abdula in the movie "Car Wash" to directing such a meaningful work of liberal art. I commend Bill Duke and all involved for bringing the Abdul Rahman story to further light.

Hollywood really needs to take this story and move with it! PRINCE AMONG SLAVES is an hour long documentary on the true life events of one Abduhl Rahman,son of the Muslim King of Futa Jallon,who was sold by rival African tribes into Europeans hands and transported to America in 1788. Purchased by a Thomas Foster,"Prince" as he was to be called,serves 40 years as a slave,marries and sires nine children,and becomes political fodder for a Mississippi News Journalist,two Presidents,one Secretary of State and for the entire American Colonization Society in his fight for freedom and return to his homeland. This is a great and absolutely fascinating true story directed and written by Lloyd Jones, Andrea Kalin (American Experience - Partners Of The Heart) and Cannes nominated Bill Duke(The Killing Floor,Miracle's Boys,Hoodlum and Rage in Harlem)."Prince" Rahman's story reads like a fairytale,but it is pointed out,quite poignantly,that much about what is known at the time,may be greatly exaggerated due to how politically motivated certain players were in "using" Rahman's story. This documentary is narrated by Mos Def and is partially "talking heads" and partially below average re-enactment for a PBS Special. THAT is my only rub with this presentation. The budget may have been low and there is subpar acting,makeup and sets. There is nothing,though,subpar about the information presented here. Other suggested documentaries of similar interest would be The Middle Passage,The Voyage of La Amistad: A Quest for Freedom as well as the feature films Amazing Grace and Amistad.

This PBS documentary tells the story of an African Prince who is brought to Mississippi in the late 18th century.  It it a beautiful and moving story that I never heard in my US History classes.  The story of Abdul-Rahman is one of hope and perserverance and truly deserves more attention  I hope it is one day made into a feature film one day.  I definitely plan on reading the book now.
I watched this documentry on PBS, I never new this story exsisted, but I was glued to the tv for the full hour. It's a great heart felt tale of a struggle and triumph. Highly recommended!

This is a good documentary. It gives a very good historical perspective on the ugliness of slavery. It highlighted the many hardships, brutalities, and horrendous conditions faced by the slaves held in captivity against their will. This documentary shows the resilience of "Prince" to rise above his plight to seek freedom for himself and his family. This documentary was painful at times to watch but the actors gave a believable portrayal of their "circumstances". The dialogue between the characters was good and the dramatic scenes brought out in me emotions of empathy, anger, sadness, and hope. This documentary may have began back in the time of slavery but it gave me food for thought today of one example of how one person can shape the course of history for generations.

EXCELLENT.....AS AN AFRICAN AMERICAN, WE ALWAYS HEAR STORIES FROM THE ELDERS THAT WE COME FROM KINGS AND QUEENS, THIS FILM HELPS TO REALIZE THE SPIRITS THAT MOVE WITHIN OUR HEARTS AND MINDS.  LOVE ALWAYS.

This provides another layer of complexity to a painful era in American History. Contrary to popular myth, the Africans brought to North America in chains were not uneducated savages. In the case of Prince Abdul Rahman, he was highly educated spoke and read numerous languages. He was in fact, more educated that his illiterate white slave owner.
I highly recommend this video as tool to explore the historical roots of white privilege. It glosses over the brutality of the slave trade and the slave market. Instead it focuses specifically on the concept that white men are inherently better and their interests trump everything else.  While the founding fathers were saying all men are created equal, the reality was,  they tolerated enormous amounts of inequality to win freedom from Britain. The history of this country since has been one of reconciling  freedom and equality.

This was a wonderful story of the hardships one man went through in order to regain his freedom and to free his family as well. Abdul Rahman, son of an African Muslim King, is taken from his home and sold into slavery in Mississippi. He marries, starts a family and eventually gains a sort of freedom for himself.  A sort of freedom that enabled him to move among many social circles to raise funds to buy the freedom of his wife and children. This documentary tells a beautiful story with a surprising and emotional ending. Definitely worth watching.

It is ironic that a leader of the Fulani Muslims in Guinea who enslaved the local African population during the conquest in the 17th century is then taken as a slave  himself.  It would have been interesting to shed light on this history of the Muslim conquest of the Futa Djallon by the Fulani and the dominance over the Bantu peoples of the region.  Really a shame that he was never able to return to the Futa to see his family.  It is a beautiful region.  Unfortunately the former master/slave  relationships still exist there, and few Bantu actually own the land that they cultivate.

The importance of Abdul Rahman's story goes far beyond the evils of the trans-Atlantic slave trade and plantation economy. The timing and context of his situation overlaps with major shifts related to class, economics, politics, diplomacy, immigration, repatriation, racial and social identity and the rise of tabloid media in our young nation. The docudrama would benefit from a few more photos and maps

I really enjoyed the movie and thought it was very well done.  He was not only a Prince among slaves he was also a prince of a man.  My heart broke for him and his family and it made me cry more than once.  I wish he could have lived long enough to see the fruits of his labor & to see all of his family brought together because of his sacrifies and deligence in order to accomplish this very difficult task.  A lot of men would have given up a long time ago but he was a true PRINCE and I don't mean his title.  I highly recommend this movie to everyone.

This movie fell short for me. For one thing, we never really got to know the main character. Of course, we feel compassion for him and his plight, but what makes him so special? Why is he more important than any other enslaved black man? Because he was a prince, he is somehow better than everyone else and deserves better treatment? The story-based-in-fact was okay in the beginning, but when this man got his freedom, he did nothing to help free other slaves. His only goal was to free his own family and get back to his own soil. Then, after begging all across the land for money (instead of fighting for the freedom of enslaved peoples) he managed to free only two of his kids and took off for Africa anyway! The story had promise, but fell short. It's like they took a story that would take five minutes to tell, and made it into a full-length movie. I felt less compassion for this man than I've felt for just about any other enslaved human I've read about or seen in movies--and certainly less than any character in Roots.

Fascinating! As a scholar of African-American history, and African-American myself, I was delighted to find this documentary here. This is a story that should be told far and wide, as it teaches that most fundamental of ideas, stated quite clearly in the film, which is that our history did NOT begin with slavery, it began with freedom. This film is a wonderful testament to the human spirit and highly entertaining.

It is important that the U.S. Black know that their History does not begin with slavery. It is good to see movies that show that. There are many stories like this that are yet to be told. It is good to know who your grandparents and great grandparents are so you can tell your children and they can tell their children. It is good.

This was the first i've heard about Adul Rahman story... i wish it would be included in US history courses/classes.  I also would have liked to see all his american descendants change their last name from the slave owner 'Foster" to Rahman as a testament to their heritage as well as a distinct rebuke of slave ownership.
